;美国央行发布了;周三普遍预期暂停;，并上调经济预测，并警告称对抗通胀的斗争远未结束，导致华尔街股市疲软。

;

;美联储更新的季度预测显示关键利率有可能在 2023 年再次上调至 5.50%-5.75% 的峰值，并且到 2024 年利率将比之前预期大幅收紧。

;

;但是，;一些投资者怀疑;央行会坚持立场，尽管自 2022 年 3 月以来政策制定者开始实施货币政策紧缩行动以来，对美联储强硬态度的押注大多适得其反。

;

;“虽然点阵图表明利率存在上行风险，但我们仍然预计加息周期可能会到来瑞银全球财富管理首席投资官 Mark Haefele 表示：“多种因素可能会给第四季度的经济带来压力，并推动美联储加息。”由于低于趋势的增长和较低的核心通胀，利率仍处于搁置状态。”

;

;根据 CME 的 FedWatch 工具，交易员对 11 月和 12 月基准利率保持不变的押注分别为 71% 和 53% .

;

;投资者还将关注经济数据，包括8月份每周失业救济金申请和成屋销售数据，以获取有关利率轨迹和经济状况的线索。

;波兰政府发言人周四表示，由于双边关系恶化，波兰仅向乌克兰执行先前商定的武器交付。波兰议会选举前几周发生的粮食争端。

;

;波兰决定延长对乌克兰粮食进口的禁令，这惹恼了基辅。直到最近，波兰一直被视为乌克兰在与俄罗斯的战争中最坚定的盟友之一。

;

;总理马特乌什·莫拉维茨基 (Mateusz Morawiecki) 周三表示，作为北约成员国，波兰不再武装乌克兰，而是专注于重建乌克兰。自己的武器库存。

;

;“我想通知您，波兰仅执行先前商定的弹药和军备供应，”政府发言人皮奥特·穆勒周四对国营通讯社人民行动党表示。 “这包括与乌克兰签署的合同产生的后果。”

;

;当被问及莫拉维茨基对武器供应的评论时，国有资产部长雅采克·萨辛表示：“目前正如总理所说，未来我们拭目以待。”

;

;萨辛表示，粮食进口争端并不意味着波兰不再支持乌克兰对抗俄罗斯，而是华沙需要补充自己的武器库存。

;

;“在这种情况下，波兰的利益是第一位的，”他说。 “我们无法解除波兰军队的武装，我们无法摆脱我们安全所必需的武器。”

;

;“在我们可以安排武器转移的地方，我们都做到了，而且我们非常慷慨这件事……我们绝对没有什么可自责的。”

;

;自俄罗斯 2 月入侵以来，波兰已向乌克兰提供了 T-72 和豹式坦克、装甲车和榴弹炮等武器。 2022 年 2 月 24 日。华沙尚未公布其提供的所有物资的完整清单。

;

;最近访问波兰的一名美国官员驳斥了有关莫拉维茨基的言论表明西方与乌克兰的团结出现裂痕的说法。

;

;“我们都是人，都会有紧张的时刻……但这并不意味着联盟团结、甚至波兰支持乌克兰的基本立场和决心会发生一些戏剧性的转变。这位不愿透露姓名的官员表示。

;

;波兰将于 10 月 15 日举行议会选举，执政的民族主义法律与正义党 (PiS) 参选。 ;来自极右翼的批评;说的是政府对乌克兰的屈从态度。

;

;联邦党表达了反乌克兰情绪，在许多民意调查中排名第三，并已成为可能的拥护者。分析人士表示，法律与正义党对乌克兰的强硬言论是对联邦日益受欢迎的回应

;

;智库Polityka Insight的防务分析师Marek Swierczynski表示，虽然波兰目前没有更多武器可以提供，但这可能是事实。乌克兰，莫拉维茨基一定知道他发表评论的时机意味着他们将“像手榴弹一样落入粪坑”。

;

;“在我看来，这更多的是一场运动的升级......为了赢得胜利波兰反乌克兰选民的比例增加了几个百分点。”他说。

;美国众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy) 将于周四尝试重启陷入僵局的共和党支出议程，并对财政预算案进行程序性投票共和党人已经两次未能推进 2024 年国防拨款法案。

;

;众议院预计将就这项 8,860 亿美元的法案进行公开辩论，而就在麦卡锡的多数派在众议院举行会议的第二天之后;2-1/2小时闭门会议;旨在在立法上找到共同点，以避免政府在不到一周半的时间内关闭。

;

;“我们将进行投票，”麦卡锡周三晚间对记者说。 “我认为我们已经有了一个前进的计划。”

;

;麦卡锡表示，共和党人也“非常接近”一项被称为持续决议（CR）的短期融资措施，并预测他将能够推进其他长期支出立法。

;

;为了避免 10 月 1 日政府关门，众议院和民主党领导的参议院必须就短期或长期支出立法达成一致，民主党将乔·拜登总统随后可以签署成为法律。但共和党人希望很快开始通过的党派措施面临参议院民主党人和白宫的强烈反对。

;

;共和党的支出议程与一小部分人发生了冲突;共和党强硬保守派;，他们希望保证 2024 财年拨款不会超过2022 年的收入为 1.47 万亿美元，比麦卡锡和拜登 5 月份同意的金额少了 1200 亿美元。

;

;周二，麦卡锡不得不对拟议的 30 天 CR 进行程序性投票。随后，关于国防拨款法案的公开辩论投票失败。本月早些时候，国防法案已被推迟。

;

;共和党的僵局引发了人们对国会在当前资金于 9 月 30 日到期时维持联邦机构运转的能力的担忧。

;

;但麦卡锡周三告诉记者，他已经赢得了周二加入民主党反对国防拨款法案的五名强硬派中两人的支持。麦卡锡以 221 比 212 的微弱优势，在民主党反对的措施上可以承受不超过四票的损失。

;

;在麦卡锡提出为期 30 天的 CR 后，两位强硬派似乎改变了立场。据两位熟悉讨论的消息人士透露，将支出削减至 2022 年的水平。 CR 将包括一个委员会来解决联邦债务问题以及对移民和边境的保守限制。

;

;消息人士称，麦卡锡的提议还将 2024 年全年财政支出设定为略低于 1.53 万亿美元的顶线

;

;目前尚不清楚 CR 或 2024 年顶线将获得众议院共和党人的多少支持。

;

;但麦卡锡对 CR 表示乐观。

;

;“我们非常接近，”他说。 “我觉得我还需要多一点运动才能去那里。”

;

;乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽连斯基 (Volodymyr Zelenskiy) 周四访问美国国会大厦，共和党怀疑论者质疑国会是否应批准新一轮援助尽管在打击俄罗斯侵略者方面进展慢于预期，但泽连斯基前往华盛顿;在寻求支持;联合国的国际支持后，进行了一场跨城闪电战，其中包括在五角大楼与美国总统乔·拜登和军事领导人会面，并在晚上发表讲话上午，泽连斯基将与共和党领导的众议院和众议院国家安全委员会的领导人会面，然后与美国参议院全体会议举行非公开会议。

;<虽然拜登和大多数国会领导人仍然支持对乌克兰的援助，而且拜登的民主党控制着参议院，但泽连斯基将面临比访问华盛顿时更强大的人群 ;九个月前;。

;

;乌克兰的军事反攻正在进行，国会上演了;关于政府可能关闭之前的支出的激烈辩论;，越来越多的共和党人质疑华盛顿为满足军事、经济和人道主义需求而向基辅提供的数十亿美元。

;

;自俄罗斯入侵乌克兰以来，美国已向基辅提供了约 1,130 亿美元的安全和人道主义援助，以帮助泽连斯基政府。 2022 年 2 月。

;

;拜登政府官员于周三晚上向国会举行了一次机密简报会，;推动追加240亿美元;，称如果让俄罗斯总统普京控制乌克兰并推进到北约边境，美国的代价将是巨大

;

;但一些共和党人并不相信。

;

;“如果乌克兰有什么胜利之路，我今天没有听到。我还听说，资金请求将永无止境。”乌克兰援助的直言不讳的批评者、共和党参议员乔什·霍利 (Josh Hawley) 告诉记者。

;

;拜登将 ;宣布向乌克兰提供新的 3.25 亿美元军事援助计划;，预计将包括第二批155毫米榴弹炮发射的集束弹药。

;

;“如果我们允许乌克兰被瓜分，任何国家的独立都安全吗？” 拜登;。

;

;国会轻易地批准了对乌克兰的援助，因为双方都认为乌克兰的援助是安全的。参议院和众议院由民主党控制。泽连斯基已成为国家的有力拥护者，被视为英雄;当他在 12 月;国会联席会议上发表讲话时。

;

;参议院中来自拜登的民主党和共和党同僚的支持仍然强劲。

;

;“乌克兰的胜利和欧洲安全符合我们国家的根本利益，”参议院共和党领袖米奇·麦康奈尔周三在参议院讲话中表示，他批评拜登在帮助乌克兰方面行动过于缓慢。

;

; ;路透社/益普索民意调查显示，绝大多数美国人支持向乌克兰提供武器以抵御俄罗斯;.

;

;但是，一些在一月份以微弱优势控制众议院的共和党人质疑继续向基辅提供资金是否明智。大约三分之一的众议院共和党核心小组 ;7 月份投票支持削减对乌克兰资金的提议失败了。

;

;共和党议长凯文·麦卡锡没有在周四安排一次会议，让泽连斯基能够阐述他继续向整个众议院提供援助的理由，而只是与他举行了一次小型会议他本人和其他几位领导人。作为议长，麦卡锡控制着众议院投票的立法内容，他说泽连斯基需要说服他支持继续提供援助。

;

;“泽连斯基当选国会议员了吗？他是我们的总统吗？我不必这样做做任何事情，”麦卡锡周二告诉记者。 “我有问题要问他。我们已经花掉的钱的责任在哪里？胜利的计划是什么？我想这就是美国公众想知道的。”

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 18:25:04 +0800 Insight: NextEra workers roll the dice with big bet on company stockhttps://reuters.com/article/nextera-energy-retirement-nsight/nextera-workers-roll-the-dice-with-big-bet-on-company-stock-idUSKBN30R0PD

;

;NextEra Energy 为员工提供的 54 亿美元退休计划今年因对公司的过度押注而蒙受了约 5 亿美元的损失股价下跌，反映了鼓励集中持有公司股票的企业 401(k) 政策的持续风险。

;

;美国最大的可再生能源公司是包括埃克森美孚和南方公司在内的几家美国能源和公用事业公司之一，促进工人退休计划中对公司股票的大规模、集中押注。

;

;路透社对退休政策和股票表现数据的分析，以及对退休和金融专家的采访，显示了美国企业界的一个小而突出的角落即使在诸如 630 亿美元的安然公司倒闭等备受瞩目的企业内爆之后，公司股票仍然在员工福利计划中进行着冒险游戏。

;

;NextEra 的 401(k) 退休计划中近 50% 的投资由员工资助在公司股票中，是标准普尔 500 指数公用事业板块所有 30 家公司中最高的 ;(.SPLRCU)< /a>;.根据路透社对 2022 年财务报表的分析，该指数的公司股票余额总额为 130 亿美元，占 904 亿美元投资的 14%。

;

;NextEra 的策略因财务顾问的不明智而失宠。在大多数公司 401(k) 计划中，为公司总部提供税收减免，而员工则承担集中持有单一股票的所有风险。

;

;相比之下，92% 的美国员工退休账户中没有住房- 公司股票，根据 Vanguard Group 对 500 万 401(k) 参与者进行的 2022 年分配研究，许多公司要么不为这些计划发行股票，要么对其进行限制。

;

;NextEra ;(NEE.N);政策激励员工将退休基金投资于其股票。根据退休计划的财务报表，它对员工可以分配多少公司股票没有限制，将员工的贡献与公司股票而不是现金相匹配，并让员工可以选择将这些持有的股息再投资到更多股票。;

;NextEra 拒绝就其在员工 401(k) 计划中使用公司股票的情况发表评论。公司发言人表示：“我们没有什么可提供的。”波士顿学院退休研究中心主任艾丽西亚·穆内尔 (Alicia Munnell) 表示，不多元化“是一件疯狂的事情”。“如果事情进展顺利，在你的公司表现得非常糟糕，你可能会失去工作和退休储蓄。”

;

;过去十年，随着公司的快速发展，NextEra对其股票的依赖为员工带来了巨大的回报，带来了总回报325%，而标准普尔 500 指数的回报率为 212%。

;

;但由于利率上升增加了公司雄心勃勃地推出风能和太阳能业务的成本，员工们最近受到了伤害。公用事业股票股息在利率较高的环境下，收益率对投资者的吸引力似乎也降低了。

;

;自 2021 年底以来，NextEra 股价已下跌 27%，而标准普尔 500 公用事业指数则下跌 11%，其价值大幅缩水根据该计划的财务报表，员工持有的 NextEra 股票减少了超过 5 亿美元。

;

;财务报告显示，去年员工因出售股票而实际损失了近 6600 万美元。

;

; 截至 2000 年底，即该公司破产前几个月，安然公司 21.4 亿美元的退休计划将其 62% 的资产投资于该公司的普通股和优先股。员工们因在财务问题日益严重的情况下被禁止出售股票而蒙受了巨大损失，然后他们失去了工作。

;

;最近，硅谷银行 (Silicon Valley Bank) 倒闭后，SVB 金融公司 (SVB Financial Corp) 在 3 月份破产，抹掉了母公司股票的几乎所有价值。

;

;波士顿郊区达罗财富管理公司总裁克里斯汀·麦肯纳 (Kristin McKenna) 表示，很多时候她的新客户并不知道他们的退休账户中的头寸集中。

;

; “这是规则，而不是例外，”麦肯纳说。 “如果我们看到单一公司股票的集中度超过20%，我们肯定会告诉他们这是一个很大的风险。”

;

;近年来，许多美国上市公司都对股票进行了限制。将公司股票集中于退休计划，并提供更多元化的计划，其中包括廉价的目标日期基金，这些基金根据投资者的年龄自动分配股票和债券，并在他们接近退休时降低风险。

;

;但也存在一些问题美国证券交易委员会 (SEC) 披露的信息显示，能源和公用事业领域有许多值得注意的大型企业坚持抵制。

;

;截至 2022 年底，埃克森美孚的退休储蓄计划持有 84 亿美元的公司股票，占总投资 211 亿美元的 40% 。与更加多元化的投资组合相比，这一押注一直落后。过去十年，埃克森美孚 101% 的总回报率落后于更广泛的标准普尔 500 指数 212% 的回报率。

;

;埃克森美孚拒绝发表评论。

;

;员工退休计划超配股票，通过提供总部的税收减免机会。例如，公司可以扣除员工退休账户中持有的公司股票所支付的股息。这对公用事业和能源行业的公司最为有帮助，这些行业的股息支付率最高，而且其 401(k) 计划中本土股票的集中度最高。

;

;很少有公司披露这一影响的影响。根据向美国证券交易委员会提交的文件，那些确实表示影响足够大，可以降低 21% 联邦税率的公司。

;

;南方公司 ;(SO.N); 最近将税率降低了多达 4 个百分点年。美国证券交易委员会披露的信息显示，截至 2022 年底，这家总部位于佐治亚州亚特兰大的公用事业公司的 76.5 亿美元退休计划中，有 38% 投资于公司股票。该公司没有回复寻求评论的消息。

;

;2021 年，Dominion Energy Inc ;(DE.N); 公司发言人瑞安·弗雷泽 (Ryan Frazier) 表示，在其受薪员工退休计划中，公司股票持有量限制为 20%，这是多元化承诺的一部分。

;

;尽管如此，最近，自治领计划的损失惨重。截至去年底，该计划持有的 Dominion 股票价值 6.87 亿美元，占 39 亿美元资产的 18%。 SEC 披露的信息显示，这些股票的成本基础为 7.58 亿美元，这意味着员工损失了 7100 万美元。此后，Dominion的股价下跌了22%。 “

;

;退休地质学家基思·拉斯穆森 (Keith Rasmussen) 表示，他仍然感受到在退休计划中大举押注公司股票所带来的财务影响。

;

;他第一次感到震惊是在公司短暂任职期间。安然公司的石油和天然气部门，当时他以每股 5 美元的价格出售了数千股股票。他说，当他收到这些股票时，这些股票的平均价值为 35 美元。

;

;十多年后，拉斯穆森因天然气价格下跌压垮了他退休计划所持股票的价值而遭受了重大损失。切萨皮克能源公司 (Chesapeake Energy Corp) 的退休计划在 2013 年底持有公司股票 46% 的资产。

;

;“我的 401(k) 被削减了一半，”68 岁的拉斯穆森 (Rasmussen) 在电话中回忆道面试。 “我们可以支付账单，但我们想做和计划做的事情受到了一些限制。”

;根据路透社/益普索 (Reuters/Ipsos) 为期两天的民意调查，美国人普遍支持汽车行业和好莱坞的罢工工人。周三，这一行动得到了民主党和共和党的大力支持。

;

;民意调查发现，58% 的美国人支持;美国汽车工人联合会;反对福特汽车;(FN);，通用汽车;(GM.N); 和克莱斯勒母公司 Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI)< /a>; 赢得更好的薪酬和福利，而 32% 的人反对这一行动，10% 的人表示不确定。

;

;同样，60% 的美国人支持双重;编剧和演员罢工;，以在娱乐行业赢得更好的报酬和保护，27%的人反对，13%的人反对不确定。

;

;民意调查发现民主党人的支持尤其强烈，他们传统上与工会结盟。大约 72% 的自称民主党人表示支持汽车工人罢工，79% 的人表示支持好莱坞罢工。

;

;大量共和党人也表示支持罢工工人，尽管他们的政党已经传统上推行亲商政策，并对许多好莱坞名人所拥护的自由主义观点持怀疑态度。

;

;民意调查发现，48%的共和党人支持汽车工人罢工，47%的人反对。同样，46% 的人表示支持好莱坞罢工，46% 的人表示不支持。

;

;这种分歧在 2024 年共和党总统提名之战中得到了体现。以大幅领先优势领先的前总统唐纳德·特朗普计划跳过 9 月 27 日举行的下一场候选人辩论，;相反，向汽车工人和其他蓝领工会成员发表演讲;。

;

;其他候选人，例如 Nikki Haley 和 Tim Scott，说汽车工人;要求太多;。;。民主党总统乔·拜登站在美国汽车工人联合会一边，呼吁汽车公司向罢工工人做出更多让步，他已将工会外展作为其 2024 年连任竞选的核心部分。根据爱迪生研究公司的数据，他在 2020 年大选中赢得了 57% 的工会家庭，而特朗普则赢得了 40%。

;

;这项民意调查是在美国出现;工会活动有所增加;。整个 8 月（UAW 罢工之前），有 31 万名美国工人参与停工，这使得 2023 年有望成为自 2019 年以来罢工最繁忙的一年。

;

;该民意调查还发现劳工运动得到了广泛支持总体而言，尽管美国私营部门工会会员人数仍处于历史低位。

;

;约 61% 的受访者表示，工会改善了所有美国人的生活质量，而只有 35% 的受访者表示，工会改善了所有美国人的生活质量。工会不再是必要的。

;

;三分之二的人表示首席执行官和工人的工资应该平等上涨——这是 UAW 罢工的核心话题。

;

;针对 1,005 名美国人的在线民意调查成人调查于 9 月 19 日至 9 月 20 日期间进行。误差范围为正负 4 个百分点，民主党和共和党的反应误差为 6 个百分点。

;

;"Set decorator for 20 years. Single mom of 15-year-old twins," said the sign above a table of cupcakes, cookies and other baked goods for sale. "Struggling to pay bills, especially my mortgage."

;

;A prop master nearby was selling handmade quilts, normally a side gig, to help make ends meet. "I now work two part-time jobs just to barely pay rent and utilities," her sign read.

;

;The signs dotting a parking lot flea market described the hardships of crew members who have been out of work for months, collateral damage from twin strikes that shut down most scripted production across Los Angeles. Hollywood writers ;walked off the job in May;, followed by ;actors in July;.

;

;IATSE, the union that represents lighting technicians, costume designers and others who work on film and TV crews, estimates that even though its members are not on strike, they have lost close to $2 billion in wages after productions shut down. Members have pulled $44 million from their retirement plans to cover current expenses, the union says.

;

;"Members are really starting to feel the pressure," said Dejon Ellis, business manager with IATSE Local 80.

;

;The motion picture and sound recording industries shed 17,000 jobs in August because of the strikes, according to US government statistics.

;

;Through mid-September, lost output from the strikes was estimated at around $5 billion across California and other production-heavy states such as Georgia and New Mexico, said Kevin Klowden chief global strategist at the Milken Institute, a think tank that studies the economy.

;

;Writers and actors can apply for assistance from their unions, and some crew members are eligible for state unemployment benefits.

;

;But that is not enough to cover basic costs of living, many entertainment industry workers said.

;

;Daniel Fox, owner of North Pole Props, was liquidating his entire inventory at the crew-member flea market. His business had barely survived COVID, he said, and it was costing too much to store items that were no longer in demand.

;

;"We definitely waited as long as we could," Fox said as shoppers browsed his collection of furniture, glassware and other props. "We just can't hold on any longer."

;

;Laura Seaman, the quilt maker, said she took a part-time job at the fabric store where she buys supplies. She also landed a role playing a monster at the Knott's Berry Farm theme park during Halloween festivities.

;

;"I make enough pretty much for rent, and that's it," she said.

;

;Around 65 people impacted by the strikes were selling memorabilia, baked goods, props or household items pulled from their own closets, according to flea market organizer Greg S. Gilday.

;

;Gilday, a prop maker, said he had about $2,000 in debt when writers walked off the job in May. By late August, that had jumped to more than $25,000. He sold a motorcycle and was trying to earn more cash from his collection of Star Wars toys, vintage magazines and other items.

;

;Film and television workers also have been competing for jobs as cashiers, waiters or babysitters.

;

;Tiffany Puterbaugh, a costume designer and stand-up comic, said the large number of people affected by the strikes left few opportunities.

;

;"There's no bartending jobs because every single person that is affected is like 'oh, I'll take any job that's available,'" Puterbaugh said. "There's nothing."

;

;Puterbaugh said she has been selling furniture and vintage clothing collected from her work.

;

;"I've been a literally starving artist for many years, so I get what it's like to be like scrappy and do side hustles," she said. "But this is really something I've never really experienced."

;

;California Governor Gavin Newsom is considering whether to allow striking workers to apply for unemployment benefits. If he does sign the bill approved by the state legislature, the measure will not kick in until January.

;

;It is unclear when the work stoppages might be resolved. Hollywood studios resumed negotiations with the Writers Guild of America this week, but no talks were scheduled with the SAG-AFTRA actors union.

;

;In the meantime, stars including George Clooney, Dwayne Johnson and Meryl Streep have donated millions to Hollywood charities that assist industry workers.

;

;IATSE gave $4 million earmarked for its members to aid organizations, Ellis said. That is long gone. It now has a GoFundMe page and operates a food pantry.

;

;"We're trying not to go into our strike fund because it's not our strike," Ellis said.

;

;Top Hollywood names also put together an auction to help crew members who have lost health insurance. On offer was a watercolor of the winner's dog painted by actor John Lithgow and a Zoom session with Nicole Kidman.

;

;Writer Andrea Tyler said she has benefited from generous friends who offer help. She keeps her car parked and walks as much as possible to avoid paying for gas, now near $6 a gallon.

;

;She eats most of her meals during the day at picket lines, where donated food is available.

;

;"The end of the month always brings this panic of how am I going to get this done?" Tyler said at a picket outside Netflix ;(NFLX.O);.

;The United Auto Workers (UAW) and the Detroit Three automakers on Thursday have a final full day to make significant progress on a new contract before the union plans to otherwise announce an expansion of its US strikes.

;

;The standoff is fueling worries about prolonged industrial action that could disrupt production and ripple through the supply chain and dent US economic growth.

;

;The UAW last week launched ;unprecedented, simultaneous strikes; at one assembly plant each of General Motors ;(GM.N);, Ford ;(FN); and Chrysler parent Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI);.

;

;Stellantis on Wednesday joined GM and Ford in ;furloughing some employees; at other factories because of the ripple effects of the strikes, including parts shortages, storage constraints and other issues.

;

;UAW President Shawn Fain said in a video released late on Monday that he would announce an ;expansion of the strikes; at 12 pm EDT on Friday (1600 GMT), barring "serious progress" in talks.

;

;"We're not waiting around. And we're not messing around," he said at the time.

;

;UAW workers are expected to rally at one of Ford's two Louisville, Kentucky assembly plants on Thursday evening in support of workers striking at other plants.

;

;The city is home to Ford's Louisville assembly plant and its Kentucky truck plant. Ford CEO Jim Farley has previously said the Kentucky truck plant, which assembles F-Series trucks, is the company's most profitable plant globally.

;

;Analysts expect plants that build high-margin pickup trucks such as Ford's F-150, GM's Chevy Silverado and Stellantis' Ram to be the next targets if the walkout continues.

;

;Fain has said Detroit automakers have not shared their huge profits with workers while enriching executives and investors.

;

;GM President Mark Reuss on Wednesday ;rejected claims; by the union that the record profits automakers make go toward fueling "corporate greed," saying they have been reinvested in electric vehicles as well as gasoline-powered cars.

;

;In the opinion piece published in the Detroit Free Press, Reuss also called UAW's demands for a 40% pay hike "untenable," signaling the two sides remain far apart over the key issue.

;

;The three automakers have proposed 20% raises over 4-1/2 years.

;

;UAW workers also want to end a tiered wage structure that they say has created a large gap between newer and older employees, forcing some to ;work two jobs; to make ends meet.

;

;S&P said the strikes were highly likely to last several weeks, potentially cutting third-quarter US gross domestic product by 0.39% and causing "upheaval" across global automotive supply chains.

;

;The ongoing walkout at mid-sized truck factories benefits rival Toyota Motor ;(7203.T);, which does not have unions at its US factories and is about to launch redesigned Tacoma pickup trucks, S&P added.

;

;Tesla investors have said a potential hike in wages and benefits at Detroit competitors would widen the EV giant's labor cost structure advantages.

;PHILADELPHIA (Reuters) - David McCormick, a former hedge fund executive who lost the Republican primary for Pennsylvania's open Senate seat last year, will announce on Thursday that he is running again for Senate — this time against three-time incumbent Democratic Senator Bob Casey Jr.

;;
;;FILE PHOTO: Republican Party US Senate candidate David McCormick speaks to supporters alongside his wife, Dina Powell McCormick, at an election night event in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, US May 17, 2022. Picture taken May 17, 2022. REUTERS/Quinn Glabicki/File Photo;
;

;A US Army veteran and former Treasury Department official, McCormick, 58, will kick off one of the nation's most closely watched races with a speech in Pittsburgh, two sources said. Reuters first reported on Sept. 12 that the former CEO of Bridgewater Associates, one of the world's largest hedge funds, would run.

;

;Pennsylvania, one of the nation's most politically competitive states, has tilted toward Democrats in recent years. Republicans in 2022 faced several losses in the state, including candidates for Senate and governor backed by former President Donald Trump.

;

;Republicans view the seat as a potential game-changer in 2024 for control of Congress. Democrats are defending a one-seat Senate majority while facing tough incumbent races in West Virginia, Ohio and Montana - states who backed Donald Trump and other Republicans in recent elections.

;

;The Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan newsletter, describes the race McCormick is joining as leaning Democratic.

;

;US Senate Republicans focused on McCormick as they try to line up fresh candidates for 2024, after newcomers with fringe views cost them seats in 2022. Republicans believe he is moderate enough to appeal to suburbanites and stable enough to help other candidates on the ticket.

;

;Pennsylvania had a Republican senator and a Democratic senator for more than a decade until Republican Patrick Toomey retired in January. US Senator John Fetterman, a Democrat, picked up the Toomey seat last year after beating television celebrity physician Mehmet Oz.

;

;The McCormick campaign did not respond to requests for comment.

;

;McCormick's decision comes after weeks of wrangling over whether Trump at the top of the ticket could be a drag, making it more difficult to oust the well-funded Casey, 63. The popular sitting Democratic senator, whose father was a Pennsylvania governor, has won three state-wide election.

;

;McCormick is already facing attacks from Democrats about whether he truly lives in Pennsylvania. He changed his residency from Connecticut last year to run for office, but The Associated Press reported last month that McCormick still rents a $16 million mansion in Connecticut.

;

;Travel boom has delivered bumper earnings for US carriers, but no-frills airlines such as Frontier ;(ULCC.O); and Spirit ;(SAVE.N); are struggling to return to sustainable profitability.

;

;That has made some of them weigh premium-price offerings, including first-class seats, customer lounges and branded foods even as they expect fares to remain the primary driver for bookings.

;

;Ultra low-cost carriers offer a no-frills experience at rock-bottom fares and charge heavily for ancillary services.

;

;They were tipped to be the big winners after the pandemic, but persistent operational constraints have exacerbated their cost pressures, making it imperative to find new high-margin revenue streams.

;

;With consumers more willing to splurge on travel, ;demand for premium cabins; has gone up. This together with soaring bookings for flights to Europe and Asia have allowed the legacy airlines - Delta ;(DAL.N);, United ;(UAL.O); and American ;(AAL.O); - to mitigate inflationary pressures.

;

;Budget carriers lack these products.

;

;Frontier CEO Barry Biffle said while he will not invest in long-haul jets, he has been struck by a greater desire among leisure travelers to pay for first-class seats on domestic flights.

;

;Frontier is watching the trend "very carefully" and would consider adding premium seats if it lasts for multiple years, he said.

;

;"If people are really willing to pay that much for a premium, maybe there is an opportunity," Biffle told Reuters.

;

;Similarly, Minneapolis-based ultra-low-cost carrier Sun Country ;(SNCY.O); is contemplating opening an airport lounge and offering branded food and beverage. CEO Jude Bricker said the demand for services that offer even minor improvements to the travel experience has doubled.

;

;"We're in discussions about things that I would have written off in the past," Bricker said.

;

;These offerings, however, entail a dilution of the traditional no-frills business model that powered the earnings of budget carriers before the pandemic. They also run the risk of inflating costs.

;

;Frontier's Biffle called adding premium seats a "big decision" and a "fairly expensive" move. That's why he is not ready to change Frontier's business model "overnight."

;

;In the meantime, he is doubling down on costs. Frontier plans to rework its network to allow almost all of its planes to return to their stations every night, with a goal to contain disruptions and save money.

;

;No-frills carriers operate a single fleet, fly their aircraft longer each day, and put more seats on every plane.

;

;Operational constraints have upended that playbook. A shortage of ;air-traffic controllers; has marred Frontier's operations. Sun Country is grappling with ;a shortfall of captains;. Spirit has been forced to ;ground several planes; due to ;RTX's RTX.N engine problem;.

;

;As a result, ultra low-cost carriers have not been able to fully utilize their fleets - a strategy they relied upon before the pandemic to lower operating costs and boost profits.

;

;Meanwhile, ;surging pilot pay rates; have ballooned costs. Privately-owned Avelo Airlines has seen a 75% jump in its pilot wage bill in the past two years. The bill is expected to increase by another 10% following hefty pay raises at major carriers, CEO Andrew Levy said.

;

;Weakening pricing power in their domestic market, as well as a jump in fuel prices, have only added to ;their troubles;.

;

;Biffle last week said Frontier is facing pressure to offer "very, very low" fares to fill up its planes. Spirit has cut its profit outlook for the current quarter, citing "heightened promotional activity with steep discounting."

;

;Frontier's shares are down by half this year. Spirit shares are down 18%. In contrast, shares of United and Delta are up 20%, and American's shares have gained 5%.

;

;The divergence in performance has sparked questions about the business model of low cost, low fares.

;

;United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby has called the model "doomed" as he doesn't expect the constraints would go away anytime soon. Some analysts are also calling for a review.

;

;"I don't know that the model is completely broken, but I certainly think that it needs to be rethought," said Helane Becker, airline analyst at TD Cowen.

;

;CEOs of budget carriers, however, don't see the model losing its appeal as long as fares determine travel bookings. The share of discount carriers in domestic passenger traffic has gone up after the pandemic, data from trade group Airlines for America shows, thanks to travelers like Jacob Brown.

;

;The 23-year-old Denver-based school teacher calls himself a "big fan" of ultra-low-cost airlines. He has been using Frontier's unlimited $140 monthly flight pass, which he said translates into an average one-way fare of about $15.

;

;"I can't afford to fly Delta enough on my measly salary," Brown said. "But I can afford to fly budget carriers."

;官员称，至少 18 人在空袭中受伤，其中包括一名 9 岁女孩，一位地区州长表示，俄罗斯夜间的炮击造成两人死亡。

;今年，乌克兰拥有更好的西方提供的防空系统，但仍然在这样一个大国防御攻击是;巨大的挑战;。

;

;俄罗斯于 2019 年向乌克兰派遣了数万名军队。 2022 年 2 月，自 7 月中旬以来，空袭的重点是港口和粮食基础设施，阻碍了全球主要粮食生产国基辅出口粮食产品的努力。
